abstract.para: Physical and chemical data for lakes and streams along the oil pipeline corridor, arctic Alaska.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

description.para:
For Archival Use:
DATE RECEIVED: Oct90 DATA FILE ENTERED BY: Julie Pallant DATA FILE VALIDATION: NAME: Julie Pallant DATE: 7Oct91

para.literalLayout: Temperature, conductivity, and pH were measured in the field. Water samples were filtered through glass fiber filters (Whatman GF/C or Gelman A/E, 1.0 Ã¦m pore size) or membrane filters (0.45 Ã¦m pore size) and stored in polyethylene bottles for no longer than 4 months. Alkalinity was determined by potentiometric titration and the titration curves were analyzed by the method of Gran (Stumm & Morgan 1981). Alkalinity was then calculated from DIC concentrations and pH using the carbonate species relations in Stumm & Morgan (1981). SO4 and Cl were analyzed using a Dionex ion chromatograph. Water samples for cation analyses were preserved in the field with HCl; Ca, Mg, and Mn were analyzed by flame atomic absorption spectroscopy, and Na and K by flame emission. Soluble reactive phosphate (SRP), NO3+NO2, and NH4 were determined on a Technicon Autoanalyzer. The mean deviation from cation-anion balance was 8.3% (N=49, SE=1.6). Waters with ion imbalances greater than 10% were usually deficient in anions; alkalinity in these samples was calculated from DIC concentrations rather than measured directly. Chlorophyll a (CHLa) was extracted in 90% methanol and concentrations were calculated using equations in Wetzel & Likens (1979). Chlorophyll samples from rivers were taken by scraping a known area of rock and dissolving that material in water. Zooplankton were collected using vertical or oblique hauls of a 100 or 240 Ã¦m mesh net.
